headline: Sweeping Education and Transport Reforms Introduced Amid Fierce Debate on Cost of Living and Ministerial Conduct
summary: Parliament was dominated by the introduction of a major bill to overhaul the education system and another to reform road funding, sparking intense ideological debate. Question Time saw the Government fend off fierce attacks over the rising cost of living and allegations of a conflict of interest involving a senior minister's handling of infrastructure funds in his own electorate.

topicSummaries.topic: Government Introduces Sweeping Education System Reform Bill
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: This legislation proposes major changes to school property management, teacher regulation, and curriculum, affecting every school, teacher, and student in the country.
topicSummaries.content: The Government introduced the Education and Training (System Reform) Amendment Bill, a wide-ranging piece of legislation aimed at restructuring parts of the education sector. Education Minister Erica Stanford argued the reforms are necessary to fix a system that is failing students, citing poor initial teacher education outcomes. Key proposals include creating a new Crown agent, the New Zealand School Property Agency, to manage the school property portfolio and shifting responsibility for setting professional teaching standards from the independent Teaching Council to the Ministry of Education. Opposition parties strongly opposed the bill, with Labour's Jan Tinetti calling it an "ideological attack on teachers" that centralises power in the Beehive and politicises teaching standards, vowing that a future Labour government would repeal it. Te Pāti Māori argued the bill pushes Māori voices to the margins and strengthens barriers to education.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon JAN TINETTI (Labour)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill is yet another ideological attack on teachers and the education system as a whole. It undermines the independence of the teaching profession.

keyExchanges.speaker: CARL BATES (National—Whanganui)
keyExchanges.quote: It is a National-led Government, once again, that is fixing education in this country. It's about time the Opposition got on board.

topicSummaries.topic: PM and Opposition Leader Clash Over Economy and Rising Cost of Living
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The debate highlights the core political divide on who is responsible for household financial pressure, with record emigration and high food prices at the forefront.
topicSummaries.content: A heated exchange during Question Time saw Leader of the Opposition Chris Hipkins challenge Prime Minister Christopher Luxon on the economy, record emigration figures, and the cost of living. Hipkins cited a 50% rise in the cost of bread and kiwifruit over the past year and rising unemployment as evidence of the government's failed economic promises. The Prime Minister defended his government's record, stating it had inherited a recession and a "long COVID hangover" from the previous Labour administration. Luxon argued his government had successfully reduced inflation and interest rates, blaming past "wasteful Government spending" for the current economic challenges.

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon Chris Hipkins (Leader of the Opposition)
keyExchanges.quote: Does he still think it isn't "rocket science" for parents to buy bread and fruit for their kids, given that those basics are now too expensive for many families, with the cost of bread and kiwifruit up 50 percent in just the last year?

keyExchanges.speaker: Rt Hon CHRISTOPHER LUXON (Prime Minister)
keyExchanges.quote: Again, I'll just say to the member, food price inflation is up about 4.7 percent. It was up 12.5 percent under his Government.

topicSummaries.topic: Minister Faces Allegations of Conflict of Interest Over $27M Bridge Funding
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The accusations raise questions about ministerial conduct and the processes for allocating public funds, particularly when a minister's electorate directly benefits.
topicSummaries.content: The Labour Party launched a coordinated attack on the Government regarding a potential conflict of interest involving Minister Chris Bishop. During Question Time, Labour MPs questioned both Finance Minister Nicola Willis and Minister Bishop over a decision to redirect $27 million of Kāinga Ora funding, originally for housing-related infrastructure, to the RiverLink bridge project in Bishop's Hutt South electorate. Minister Bishop, who holds the Housing and Transport portfolios, defended the decision, stating he acted in accordance with Cabinet Office advice throughout the process and that the decision was a pragmatic response to a request from the local council. The Speaker earlier declined an application from Labour for an urgent debate on the matter.

keyExchanges.speaker: TANGI UTIKERE (Labour—Palmerston North)
keyExchanges.quote: How can he stand by that when he used Kāinga Ora funding to push through a bridge in his own electorate, a project his Government had already cut?

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS BISHOP (Minister of Transport)
keyExchanges.quote: I reject the characterisation of that. Firstly, the decision was made in relation to that as Minister of Housing, not Minister of Transport... The third point is that I have acted in accordance with Cabinet Office advice throughout this.

topicSummaries.topic: Bill to Modernise Road User Charges and Expand Tolling Passes First Reading
topicSummaries.whyItMatters: The proposed law would change how all drivers pay for roads, paving the way for petrol cars to move to a pay-per-kilometre system and allowing for more toll roads to be built.
topicSummaries.content: The Land Transport (Revenue) Amendment Bill passed its first reading, beginning a process to significantly reform road funding. Transport Minister Chris Bishop stated the bill modernises the "clunky" and "paper-based" Road User Charges (RUC) system from the 1970s, enabling electronic systems and paving the way to transition petrol vehicles to RUC in the future. The bill also expands the framework for tolling to help fund new roads. Labour supported the bill to the select committee stage but expressed concerns about the expansion of tolling, while the Green Party opposed it, arguing it would lead to the privatisation of public assets and funnel money to corporations.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon CHRIS BISHOP (Minister of Transport)
keyExchanges.quote: This bill is another step in the evolution in the approach to road funding in New Zealand. Since centralising our roading system in the 1920s, the principle that all users should contribute fairly in proportion to their use of the roads has underpinned how we fund and pay for our roading system.

keyExchanges.speaker: Hon JULIE ANNE GENTER (Green—Rongotai)
keyExchanges.quote: The reason we won't be supporting this bill is because of the very dodgy provision that allows roads to be leased to private companies for up to 50 years—for the purposes of providing tolling services that return a profit to private companies.

conclusion: The day was defined by the government advancing a sweeping and controversial reform agenda, while facing intense scrutiny over the cost of living and the conduct of one of its senior ministers.
